title: Best-In-Class Company
pros: Leadership, support, culture, wages, innovation.
cons: Excellent experience and opportunities. Nothing negative to share.

title: Wack
pros: Nothing. The people are so bland.
cons: Pay. Culture. Office hours. Expectations.

title: Nice place to work
pros: Great people in my department, wonderful benefits.
cons: I've noticed a pattern of increasing the workload for current employees by not replacing those who leave. Working from home went from twice a week to once a week.

title: Prob better than average
pros: Many long term employees Bonus structure good/generous
cons: Frequent micromanagement Promotions and pay are not equal across the board

title: Great Company Before Changes
pros: Company attempts to keep employees happy with free food and occasional fun activities. Pay is top notch compared to other companies
cons: Hybrid schedule has been changed from 2 days in office to 4 days in the last 2 years. New Leadership has changed much of the things people loved about the company and it no longer feels like it cares about its employees as much as it cares about its bottom line

title: All and All pretty good
pros: -Good leadership -Most executives are pleasant to work with -Potential for growth if you're well connected in the company
cons: Not a lot of cons, this is a good place to get a start after college if you want to get into real estate and finance.

title: Company in decline
pros: Higher bonus potential than average
cons: The person that is supposed to lead diversity is the most power hungry, unwelcoming, and unapproachable member of the team. She leads the performance process and knows nothing about Hr. The company grabbed somebody out of IT that does not know HR an it shows… HR is declining…

title: Abominable HR
pros: In my observation, if you're lucky to have a newer dept head then there is much less 'old boy networking' and you have a decent shot of being recognized and promoted.
cons: HR leadership is out-of-touch and too concerned about what the executive team thinks to actually take the job of helping employees seriously. Also the department is so full of gossip, it's embarrassing.

title: Good group of people to work with
pros: I really enjoyed my team
cons: Quite a bit of pressure to cut expenses.

title: Always Changing
pros: They tried to make it a fun workplace; the people were great. I got to work on many different kinds of projects.
cons: Favoritism was obvious, I have heard there were a lot of changes since I left so I don't know if it is like this now but, when I was there people didn't express opinions that contradicted the bosses. Everyone started mirroring the manager and she kind of mean girl mocked you if you were not part of her click.

title: Fun place to work with tons of challenges and opportunities!
pros: The atmosphere was always positive. They do a great job of hiring top-notch people so you feel surrounded by a team of peers that are competent, motivated, supportive, and really fun to be around! There was always an opportunity to learn more and grow with the company, and good employees were always encourages to apply for open positions. Awesome leadership from the top down.
cons: Long hours and some evening and weekend work, especially for managers. But with the shopping centers bustling with visitors during those times, it was always enjoyable and different from the often quiet weekday hours.

title: Malls are Dying and So is Macerich
pros: Pizza Parties every week, yay. (if you want to even call that a Pro).
cons:
Will not train.
Condescending Management.
Extremely Cliquish.

title: Absolutely awful.
pros: I thought it was my dream job...
cons: ...then they fired me for having a disability.

title: Positive
pros: Interesting Work and experience at a retail company during an evolving real estate and retail market.
cons: Large company, somewhat siloed into groups.

title: Great culture
pros: Great culture, supportive coworkers, some flexibility via hybrid schedules, and in-office perks (catered lunches, holiday activities)
cons: PTO allowance could be better, time off accrues very slowly.

title: Great Culture
pros: Company has a great culture and potential for growth.
cons: As with most REIT companies the growth opportunity can be limited.

title: Great company
pros: They offer a Great work life balance
cons: Lots of corporate politics involved.

title: Great Place to Work!
pros: Work life balance, great co workers, lots of work perks.
cons: Not sure there are any downsides

title: Solid Place to work at
pros: Everyone is really great to work with, great for someone who wants to stay at a place for a long time.
cons: Small teams, sometimes wears multiple hats but worth it.

title: Great Company Culture
pros: Great environment and coworkers committed to quality work.
cons: Can't think of anything negative

title: Great culture, slow for growth
pros: The company values employees' wellbeing and people are very professional and nice to work with. Great benefits. Beautiful new office.
cons: Pay is on the lower end and the promotion pace is very slow unless you have personal connections to the management.

title: Solid
pros: Strong culture and solid leadership
cons: The pay could be better for the level of work.

title: It all depends on the leader...
pros: Some really great leaders that work hard to build their teams and create synergy. Many higher leaders have been there for many, many years. Opportunities for growth if you are vocal about it and work hard. Comparable benefits and pay.
cons: Slow growth opportunities Unfair distribution of work. Often people are VERY overworked. Poor work/life balance. Poor senior Leadership - depending on department. Incestuous - they do not support newbies in HR with their concerns if there is history with those in leaderships that are included in the complaint.

title: Good Place
pros: Flexible Schedule for remote work
cons: There are no cons outside of normal daily tasks that can stack up

title: Pretty decent company to work for
pros: Hybrid. Decent pay. Worklife balance . Growth opportunities.
cons: Very rigid sometimes but it's expected form company this size

title: Great Company
pros: Excellent People and good work/life balance
cons: Can be slow to make strategic decisions

title: Security
pros: All the Pro's left when Gene Thompson and Dennis Scott passed. They really understood what security is and the important role that they played within the company.
cons: All the security staff is poorly trained, underpaid and constantly under pressure by a spineless manager. Never willing to stand up for the employees and only siding with his wife who works within the mall. Which is a company violation (fraternizing with mall tenants). The work environment was so hostile that everybody was back stabbing each other at every turn. Management treated the security staff like 3rd rate janitors. Some of the security supervisors would show up drunk or start drinking while on the job! It took one property manager 4 months to finally introduce himself to the staff. During those 4 months he just walked around and complained about every single bad detail the mall had and how the staff failed to observe it. The only growth here, is to quickly grow out of this property into a better place. Better yet, dump security and grow into a REAL CAREER and never look back. Macerich will never be the same and this mall (Pavilion) will end up like the Hawthorne Plaza. Time Off policies? Well, everyone steals from the time clock because they sign it themselves. They also steal from the lost and found via manipulating the report information. You can't count on the employees there. They will back stab you. If you're not part of the "click", you're in for a hard time. There too many negatives to list, so just stay away from this area and the company all together!

title: It’s pretty cool.
pros: People are cool, great environment.
cons: Unclear expectations of job and no communication.

title: Worse Place I Have Ever Worked
pros: Good health benefits Reputable company Work/life balance
cons: Work environment Management Compensation on low end

title: Amazing group of people who take pride in their work.
pros: I love the mall office environment. I've worked at several different locations and loved my coworkers at each one. Lots of autonomy to do what the team believes is best. Very exciting work environment, never live the same day twice. In the past, the company was willing to make significant investments in employee growth.
cons: Too much time spent talking about what we're going to do and not enough time spent actually executing plans. A lot of meetings, conference calls and reporting that don't generate results. Too many cooks in the kitchen with conflicting opinions leaving field level employees with lack of clear direction. Constant demand to do more with less compromises our standards. Focus has moved entirely to driving income and reducing expenses at all levels.

title: Great company to work for
pros: Great people Great leadership Variety of work
cons: Very busy Not always a stable work environment

title: Rigid very nitpicky and not a fan of remote working
pros: Good to get a experience
cons: Very nitpicking .in the department I work there is a lot of petty kind of behavior almost make you feel like you are in kindergarten and don't know anything I live very far form office .the policy is to work there twice a day in office. When I suggested it takes 3 hours of my day to drive only let me work from home and I will ho above and beyond in my work but they rejected and said it's their policy and no changes to it . And after that they have audacity to say they are very family friendly and flexible company and also they are worried that in new trend people may quite quit .. we'll what so u expect ? 12 hours of driving and woking ? You want more . Reasons were provided that we want employee to socialize .. but only people who have been there for years talk .. I havnt talked to anyone as no one really talk to you. So what is the point of being in office

title: Not a great place to work used to be better
pros: The only real reason to work here is to gain experience and build your resume and then take it with you somewhere better.
cons: Many, many cons. Based upon my experience, hostile working environment, not-so-great pay (not even really market competitive), micromanagement hell, heavy workload, few growth opportunities, upper management absolutely does not care about employees, high turnover. Typically there are layoffs every year in February like clockwork. I write all this not to be vindictive but in the hopes that someone gets some brutally honest information from a former employee’s perspective based upon their experience and that I help offer a good person some things to consider before making a decision to work there. Also, don’t believe what you read about ability to work from home. They are not flexible in that way. Raises and bonuses (if you get either) are done with extreme scrutiny and penny pinching even for the better employees. If you want to work for a typical not so great corporate America type environment, then this place is the epitome.

title: HR is incompetent and corrupt.
pros: There are very few departments at Macerich that have high retention. Those that do have happier employees, and completely ignore HR practices and programs - which are completely outdated. If you are lucky enough to be in one of those departments you will get at or above average raises and bonuses, regular promotions, and will likely be instructed to stay away from HR.
cons: The HR department has absolutely no credibility or influence in the organization. They have no professionals in HR that stand up to the bullying managers found in most parts of the company. I have heard that within HR that employee treatment is the WORST! So many at SVP and VP level continue to manage like it's 1960. The executive management team has no use for the staff level employee, they are very self-motivated and barely know employee names. The company touts being adaptable and ready for change, but that is totally untrue. So many layers and lack of empowerment makes this 'corporate value' a joke.

title: Great Company, Terrible Managers
pros: Wonderful values, nice office, great co workers, great mission statement. Holiday parties are nice.
cons: Supporting 3+ people at a time is too overwhelming, felt more like a personal assistant at times than an admin. There are too many egos and personalities to handle for one person. I think some of the people don't realize that this isn't vogue or glamour magazine they're working for, it's property management. One mistake, and they're quick to write you off and make you feel like garbage. Micro managing doesn't exist and if you ask a question, you get lectured. Upper management should have their own Personal/Admin assistant. They act like they're way too above to do certain things for themselves. I had to get out because I was tired of feeling low and afraid to attend work.

title: Not Valued
pros: First job out of college as a computer science major. I guess they took a chance on me, even though I had IT experience in college. Pay was a bit higher than average for a help desk role. Not a bad starter position, but definitely not a long-term place you want to be.
cons: I was a model employee for two years and was fired for throwing a beach ball over the cubicle divider (that hit an HR worker). OH NO! Did you get hit by an inflatable beach ball? I had already given my two weeks notice, so it didn't affect me much - but if you are a 5 star employee for years and they let you go at the drop of a hat, you can tell they don't care much for the lower levels of staff. Also give the bare minimum raises and bonus. Don't expect much.

title: Used to be a good company to work for
pros: Mild work hours during non quarter months, occasional flex work days at home, good coffee and free sodas, good office location in the SM promenade
cons: Traffic bad in office location (SM promenade), company lacks culture and unity, large division between associates and managers, very closed door feel with management, company pay was very poor, with a large portion of compensation reserved as a bonus (10%), and overall salary very low for a large public company making millions.

title: Politics, bureaucracy, and bad ideas.
pros: Fairly stable. Decent pay and benefits. Reasonable with work-life balance requirements.
cons: Who you know is much more important than what you know. Outward appearances are more important than actual results. Career advancement is very slow. Type A personalities (extroverts) rewarded, while Type B personalities (introverts) are ignored. A large portion of the company is middle management, all given "Vice President" titles. Many people in middle management seem to feel entitled to special treatment and exemption from company policies. After the original President was pushed into retirement, it seems like poor business decisions keep being made. No transparency in Executive-level operations after the original President left.

title: Macerich Review - Poor
pros: - Flexable schedules and no constant clock watching - People willing to help one another
cons: - Almost all advancement is due to who you know. Several married executaive couples in upper management and its much a bro's club. - Upper Managment is too worried about walstreet and not employees - Low paying salary compared to market and one's experience - Okay benefits (401k & Health) - Company is trying to make a smaller, yet higher quality portfolio, therefore eliminating many positions and properties. - Will demand that you work hours over and beyond what is hummanly possible at times. Work is your life!

title: Limited upside, mediocre raises, favoritism
pros: There are some great people to work with at the company
cons: There is a large chasm between groups who work here. Seemingly divided into those at the company less than 5 years, and those greater than 10 years. For those who haven't been around awhile, there is a steep climb for newer employees to be promoted and achieve meaningful pay raises. Alot of quality management personnel left the firm over the past 7 years, which left those remaining 'veterans' victorious in the war of attrition. Not all of them are the most capable... but they certainly have seniority. Work/life balance is a bit of a joke. Its preached but never provided. Expect to work late and/or on the weekends. Regularly.

title: Very progressive IT department with good management up to and including the CIO
pros: Good work conditions Great benefits package Highly skilled management team Keeping up with IT trends and solutions Good cross (IT) department collaboration Relatively quick to fix a hiring mistake Jusdt an overall great place to work!
cons: Since departure of previous CEO the transparency from the top down has taken a serious hit While the above is true, the corporate culture in the Phoenix Office has remained much the same, which is a good thing Hold accountable those that are inneffective at or just plain avoid their jobs instead of letting them get others fired

title: One of those diamond in the ruff great companies
pros: Great company that respects employees and cares about work/life balance. Wonderful family-like culture with very caring management. However, every department has a different culture. My experience in my department was very positive and I truly enjoyed working for my boss and other VP's.
cons: Next to no interdepartmental communication. If I worked in a department where I had to rely on communication between leasing or accounting, etc I can see how I would extremely frustrated. Heard many rumors that the accounting department was strict and inflexible and lended itself to a very anxiety prone environment. Also, H.R. did not seem to have their ducks in a row. Had a wonky experience when I needed advice from them.

title: The grass is not greener...
pros: Decent benefits plan when compared to the industry. In most cases interdepartmental relationships with other employees are pleasant and they actually willing to help if you ask.
cons: Segmented work environment where the left hand is not even aware of the right hands existence. Very limited communication with people outside of your work silo, often with people in the same office reporting to a different command structure. Too many layers of VP's and AVP's who seem to have no experience at a property level.

title: Great executive and SVP leadership at company.
pros: Strong executive level people running the company. Most executives consider the employees their greatest asset.
cons: ervative financial management (which is good given the current economy). Many good SVPs who have long term experience in the industry. Good benefits package.

title: Right by the Water
pros: I enjoyed my time at Macerich due to the managable workload and laid back managerial approach by my superior. The atmosphere was very comfortable and I got along with all of my coworkers especially those I worked directly with. The pay and location were also favorable.
cons: Upper management was incredibly inept and it felt that a lot of people in top positions got there due to past friendships or family connections. Despite a pleasant atmosphere one did have to look out for the occassional snitch and back stabber. There's one in every office and seemed to be more at Macerich.

title: Used to be a GREAT place to build a career
pros: The dept where I worked was full of mostly great people. There was a real team mentality and support from the C-suite down. The Westcor team always seemed to try and maintain the values and culture to keep the Macerich culture of kill or be killed at bay. If you worked in IT, the rest of the company trusted and believed in you to get things done. They really listened to the voice of the customer.
cons: Some within the team were rsther backstabbing and/or just plain incompetent. Yet, they were kept on because they hoodwinked the manager into liking them. Some managers and up should have never gotten the position they were given. It's just that some senior personnel get too attached and won't fire them. Some of those people and managers are still there today. The Macerich culture is what has ruined the brand, overall. The flippant nature of direction, without sharing with and empowering employees to make it reality, yet holding them accountable, has driven the company into a hole. I believe Macerich will end up being taken over by the likes of Simon or GGP within the decade, as they continue to back themselves into a smaller and smaller footprint to the point of irrelevancy. HR is a complete joke. One HR senior person brags of her augmentation, yet removes good people on the flimsiest of circumstances. The rest of HR is as bad or worse.

title: No growth opportunities
pros: Good benefits, 401k, good perks
cons: Too many to include all. There is no room for growth. The only people that are promoted are 95% men and only if they are friends with the CEO's or executives. There are many work environment issues such as bullying and harassment. I experienced harassment at this company after 1 year working for Macerich. Nothing happens to the people that causes problems. Even if you complain. I complained of harassment to my boss and he assured me that it was reported to corporate. I was never contacted about this issue so I'm sure it was never reported.

title: Good place to work if you have a reliable team.
pros: Good pay, great healthcare and 401K Match. When you worked with reliable team you had some flexible hours.
cons: There wasn’t a lot of support from my team in my department. I was often called up or called in on vacation and sick time or wasn’t able to take my vacation or sick time. Also, I was told to work overtime without pay.

title: Very rewarding experience being able to support both Merchants and Guests at The Oaks Shopping Center.
pros: This company values not only the Guests and Merchants but also the employees with creating a positive atmosphere of rewarding a job well done.
cons: Retail employment undoubtedly presents demanding challenges of Holiday, evening and weekend hours as well as the occasional situation in assisting a Guest that had an unsatisfactory shopping experience.

title: Don't get on board the Titanic
pros: Great people across the board and typically a very good work life balance. Very good portfolio of properties
cons: As other reviews point out nepotism is rampant at Macerich. You don't have to look very hard to find an example in the president of the company is the CEO's little brother and gets paid millions to literally do nothing. The industry is dying and Macerich will be one of the many casualties in the coming 2-3 years. The mall REITS can only play their financial reporting games for so long before it catches up

title: Manager
pros: Great work environment and easy to get along with senior management. Very friendly group of people and all of the resources to get daily tasks completed are available and adequate.
cons: There is no path for professional development. If this is not your dream position you will not be working towards such a role here.

title: IT Department
pros: Great coworkers, friendly and willing to help. Management tries to make it fun by holding monthly fun events ordering pizza, watching movies, etc.
cons: Unfortunately, as is typical of alot of IT departments the ones that are promoted to leadership roles are prior developers, etc with little management experience and unfortunately it is not a natural fit with their backgound/personality.

title: Good Company to build career
pros: Great company culture, they take care of their own. Decent room for growth if you show talent and hard work. They have great resources since it's a public company, and the people up top are very smart and approachable.
cons: You don't get much training unless you happen to get set up with a good mentor. When/if you get let go there is no loyalty to having worked for the company, they cut the chord very quickly, and harshly.

title: Good corporate vision, but management needs more oversight.
pros: They pay was a bit above average for the position. IT is available for any help you need. Some staff that have been there a long time balance out the whole office. The leasing staff was friendly despite having a lot going on. I liked working with guest services, they are huge asset, and keep a great relationship with the stores that management is ignoring. The maintenance staff was also great, they did their jobs and their management had a great work ethic and understanding of the property.
cons: Working at Broadway Plaza was a negative professional experience. The environment is negative, management projects an image of perfection and kindness to the staff and the store managers, but their own agenda and expectations are the first priority. When people considered “important” would visit our site, the expectations of perfection by property management were unrealistic. If someone in the office made a mistake during one of those visits, they would be shunned. The other staff tiptoed around the upper property management in the office. I've worked at places with the CEO in the office, and they did not expect the treatment the property management of this location did. The middle managers in the office go back and forth from being great to treating the admin staff, guest services, security, housekeeping and valet management very poorly. I witnessed other employees cry, and another employee call in sick from the parking lot because she was afraid to come in. There were relations problems with the store managers that were not the big few in the mall. The management staff would spend a week planning a lunch with 2 people and ignore problems from the majority of store managers. Employees paid hourly were asked to work overtime without compensation on multiple occasions. When I and other co-workers asked to take time off to make up for unpaid overtime it was rarely given, and never offered. In addition, while working there I and other co-workers found it very difficult when we became ill. I understand the strain on co-workers and management when an employee goes through something like that, but I and other co-workers were met with zero understanding when it came to illness. I was threatened to be let go, despite not even coming close to using all allotted sick time. No, I would not recommend working here. The lack of opportunities for training and no outreach from HR about open positions makes the negative environment not worth it.

title: Overall good place to work
pros: Great benefits and good people. They have a lot of long-term employees; if you play the politics correct, they'll protect you and do what they can to keep you happy
cons: it depends who your manager is on whether or not they respect work/life balance; you are often expected to check/respond to emails even when on vacation. Don't do your job too well or you won't be considered for other opportunities.

title: Struggling
pros: Decent benefits and pay, 3 weeks vaca after 5 years, ESPP plans. Depending on your department, the culture is fun and family like. If you get in the wrong dept.... then not so much. Work -Life balance for most Mostly everyone is nice but you pretty much stay in your department silo's.
cons: Macerich is in transition and is under constant scrutiny from investors and there are always rumors of an acquisition. They recently let go of over 100 corporate employees and have been cutting budgets at properties for awhile. The retail industry is struggling and its showing at Macerich.

title: Tough times and yet the main focus is on employees.
pros: This is a company that truly values and rewards its employees. Like any business, especially the mall business, there are challenges and tough times. Despite this, current leadership has strove to put employee morale, welfare, and teamwork as the highest priority. This will pay dividends in the long run. While there may not be short term growth, that is a worthwhile tradeoff to be part of this organization.
cons: None within. Externally, the stock price is undervalued.

title: Administrative Assistant
pros: Good pay, laid back work flow, a lot of catered luncheons, nice location, subsidized gym membership program
cons: Upper employees only care about themselves, no opportunities for training or development making this a dead-end job. Less than positive work environment due to excessive rudeness from co-workers. It seems that HR fails to take action with nasty employees who obstruct work production, these people should be replaced.

title: It was a great experience and I learned a lot.
pros: Was promoted multiple times within a short period, so they really do try to promote within. Some people in the company are great and truly wonderful to work for. No two days are alike so you don't get bored. Benefit package is among the best I've seen.
cons: So much turn-over! Always And the direction of the company is constantly changing so as soon as you get a grasp on what the goal is, it's does a 180. Pay is good, but not compared to competitors' pay.

title: Stockholder company beware
pros: Most don't know how to do their job so it makes yours much easier.
cons: Was in the upper management for some time, they only care about profits to the shareholders, don't listen to what the others say, they let people go and hire friends, Ive seen the lower staff struggle while being asked do to more with less. It's sad.

title: Marketing Manager
pros: Wish I had something positive to say. A truly negative experience.
cons: Property managers that are untrustworthy (financial improprieties), no creativity allowed, follow the company program and do what you are told. I worked for 5 different managers in one year, two of which with no experience overseeing a mall (25 years old and younger). I wouldn’t allow someone like that to manage a multi million dollar shopping center. Too much upper management making big dollars. All for me and none for you attitude. If you aren’t at one of their major properties that really don’t care. Cut the budget.

title: Listen to your employees
pros: Ability to grow, benefits are good, upper management is friendly.
cons: There is definitely some undertones when it comes to personal beliefs. HIPPA law is nonexistent here. Managers and VP’s will feel comfortable enough to talk open about vaccine status and make snarky remarks. This company is set up for remote working. But they will not allow it for whatever reason.

title: Good Benefits, Great Location, Terrible Culture
pros: Good Benefits - health, dental, decent compensation. Great Location in Santa Monica - lots of shopping & great restaurants - places to hang out with co-workers.
cons: Least creative, most boring job ever. Micro-managing supervisors who will hassle you over ever unimportant details. Also, an old boys club of Texas real estate buddies, with no real management or technical skills.

title: No one wants to make up their mind
pros: Benefits and time off. Some of the Macerich employees are very nice and good working relationships are great. I can't think of anything else. They are very mediocre..
cons: Upper Management changes their priorities constantly. Upper Management needs to understand the property management teams is in the know and should listen.. You don't have a personal life and no one notices..

title: Corporate Employee
pros: - Good benefits including health insurance options, 401(k), stock vesting option and health related seminars. - Flexible work hours. - Good company to gain experience as an entry level employee in property management field.
cons: - No connection between properties and the corporate office. Shopping Center visits by corporate employees completely stopped after the founder passed away. - No room to grow, no promotions within the company. It is sad to watch so many hard-working, talented people leaving the company for new opportunity to advance their career and for salary increases. Despite to many years of great performance reviews, promotions and salary increase does not take place unless you are friends or family of the management.

title: You are only as good as your last deal...
pros: Good education process. A top Company in the shopping center industry. The Company is a publicly traded REIT, accordingly value is the bottom line.
cons: When the founder of the Company passed away the company culture changed for the worse. The treatment of long term employees became harsh. As a publicly traded company, employees became "numbers" that could be shuffled or eliminated.

title: Senior Manager
pros: Decent Real Estate -
cons: Truly the worst experience of my professional career. Everyone is a relative or has been there for 20-30 years. Chauvinistic and arrogance beyond belief. They aren’t competitive in salaries however the average amount of hours worked in my Dept was prob @ 25- weekly full time hours so that’s why people stay. They will be the next REIT to be acquired or taken over. They are forecasting false information to Wall Street. Good luck with that Karma MAC . Run for your life before working for this company !!!!! X10 I would have scored negative stars if I could have

title: Feels Like Family
pros: This company treats employees like adults. Listens to your ideas and/or opinions, implements them if they support company objectives, and gives you credit for it. The management teams are for the most part, top notch. Working to help advance their employees' knowledge and position within the company.
cons: The salaries are sometimes below the national average, but the ancillary rewards make up for it.

title: Wonderful Part Time Oppurtunity
pros: Staff members are mostly very welcoming and helpful. The pay was decent considering the job duties. 401k was offered for part time employees.
cons: Employee Hours are very dependent on gift card sales, sales cold calling to business's with out any commission or bonus potential.

title: An experienced opinion
pros: Well established, publicly held company with good assets. Lots of opportunities if you know the right people. Great resume and networking builder.
cons: Publicly held and like any companies of this size bureaucracies tend to get in the way of everyday activity. Just a cog in a massive machine.

title: Not very good when it comes to having a work life balance.
pros: Nothing. Everything is standard. Nothing special.
cons: There’s no work life balance. You cannot call out sick without guilt tripping you. Horrible managers who does not have basic management skills to manage a team. There are undertones when it comes to race and personal beliefs beware.

title: Leasing Manager
pros: While constantly changing depending on the new management over the years, there were years where this company was known as a family and small company feel. They spent time teaching their younger hires and most people knew each other. The pay was less than other competitors, but it was an overall good environment.
cons: The environment changed, but the salary was not commensurate with the change.

title: A waste of my time... if I could do it over again, would not have taken the job.
pros: The co-CEOS of the firm mean well. I think they really want a company like Zappos, a company they went to visit to learn how they developed a positive work environment in a corporate world. That's about all the positive I can muster up. It was that bad.
cons: While the co-CEOs mean well, the problems start at the top with the Partners, all the way down to the Managers, and into the HR department. The Partners play favorites, ignoring those they dislike or don't care about. They give you a fake smile and then talk behind your back. I think there was maybe 4-5 Partners throughout the firm that I met who actually were genuine, and really cared about their staff. The rest just use the staff to make themselves look good. The managers in this firm were a mix of good and bad. The bad being those who were abusive to staff. Everyone, including Partners and HR, knew about the reputations of the bad managers, but nothing was ever done. Why? Because the abusive managers brown nosed the partners, and of course, they were friends with everyone in HR. They knew the right people to befriend, so they would be untouchable. Shameful how they allowed people to be treated. The HR department is unable to keep their mouth shut, so if you have a real complaint, your best bet is to tough it out or find another job, because if you complain about them, they usually notify the offending party, and your life becomes hell then. I saw it happen to numerous people, so I knew better than to go to HR to complain about harassment. And forget about a career here. How can you have a career when the turnover rate is ridiculous, and on top of that is the massive layoffs every 2 years (they laid off nearly 7-8% of their staff (77 people) in May, while also having another 150-200 quit or get fired after the layoff (fired separately to avoid having the layoff number be higher than it already was).

title: Became quite toxic
pros: Very cool experiences depending on your position
cons: Toxic if you aren't part of the Men's club (at least at my specific office) or related to someone higher up. No room for growth at all if you are not in these positions

title: Security Officer very satisfied with Mall job.
pros: I love the company. What started as a family owned company with a few malls has grown into a company with malls in over 10 states across the country.
cons: The hours, dealing with the kids on the weekends. Also unless you are full time there are no benefits.

title: Anonymous
pros: Experience working in a corporate environment. Based on property, you hit the ground running and quickly learn tasks of your position. Benefits are good.
cons: It is difficult to assume a higher role and get promoted. Changes occur by the minute and you need to be prepared to adapt quickly.

title: Good Intentions / Poor organization
pros: Good benefits, fair compensation and in theory they offer flexible hours but that depends on who you are, who you know and where you are on in the department hierarchy.
cons: lots of good intentions but poor project planning and asset management means some people were able to take advantage of flexible hours and other people were called in on vacation time.

title: Antiquated and Nepotistic
pros: - Good People at Property Level
cons: - Uninvolved President with no vision or leadership who is just worried about stock price and his position - Out of touch nepotistic executive mind set - Old school mentality that does not work in 2022 - No visionaries, way behind competitors and holding on to outdated business model and assets

cons: Sometimes hard for a type A manager to pull back and build a group mindset.

title: Get Out

title: Terrible company, doesn't care about their employees
pros: Flexible schedule, freedom in position, pay and benefits are good, 401k, left to my own devices and able to work on my own most of the time.
cons: Management doesn't care, no help from upper management. Basic attitude is that your on your own. Expected to work overtime even if your family obligations don't allow for that.

title: Administrative Assistant
pros: Decent benefits, schedule flexibility (depending on department).
cons: Company does not recognize contributions or reward good work - there is no reward for a job well done. Company has many times hired and promoted the wrong people - often hiring from outside instead of within. Current employees aren't even told about open opportunities.

title: Decent, but nothing special

cons: Lack of corporate culture, most work is data-entry, creativity is not rewarded or desired.

title: Used to be great, train wreck now

cons: No cons but be prepared to work weekends and holidays. If you love what you do, especially special events, t won't matter.

title: The best people I have ever worked with.

title: Top heavy, but has potential.
pros: Generally, a positive corporate culture - there are a lot of good people that work there. Excellent benefit package.
cons: Many of the departments suffer from a top heavy organizational structure, with a staggering number of vice presidents in place shoveling out projects to the property level - most of which have little, if any, apparent relevance other than justifying the existence of their positions. Limited advancement potential for individuals in non revenue generating operational positions, as those departments tend to have a much leaner organizational structure - not to mention a constant battle to justify one's own existence through countless reports and metrics since you're not bringing in money. Often the company as a whole feels like it is managed directly out of whichever management theory book is in vogue at the moment - far too much emphasis on drilling the slogan of the moment into the collective minds of the employees versus genuinely putting into practice. Becomes Dilbert-esque after a while.

title: Decent entry level position for someone coming out of college. Great advice and guidance from management.
pros: Competitive pay, decent training, company highly values its employees and treats them as true assets. High standards in property upkeep, customer experience, and marketing production. Macerich is a top notch REIT that knows what their doing.
cons: Marketing efforts can be stale at times and driven from the top down. Frivilous events with limited payback and traffic generation. Localized creativity can be stifled by corporate marketing objectives. Marketing generates little to no revenue and is the first to go in lean times.

title: great real estate company
pros: they have hard working dedicated employees working to make a difference. they have a good portfolio and continue on making it better.
cons: they use to share information about the direction of the of the company and now you have no idea. everything rolls down from the top and they do not share the company vision. not a lot of balance between work and personal life as expected to put in a lot of hours.
